animalOfTheDay.name: snow leopard
facts: Snow leopards are known as 'ghosts of the mountains' due to their elusive nature.
They have thick fur and wide, fur-covered feet that act as natural snowshoes.
They are unable to roar but communicate with chuffing sounds and growls.
Snow leopards can leap up to 50 feet in a single bound.

calendar.name: sea turtle
facts: Sea turtles can migrate thousands of miles between feeding and nesting grounds.
The temperature of the nest determines the gender of the hatchlings.
Leatherback sea turtles can dive deeper than 1,000 meters (3,280 feet).
They return to the same beach where they were born to lay their eggs.

calendar.name: seahorse
facts: Seahorses lack stomachs and must eat constantly to survive.
They are poor swimmers, relying on camouflage and slow movements to avoid predators.
They have prehensile tails to grip seagrass and corals, avoiding strong currents.
Seahorses are the only fish where males become pregnant and give birth.

calendar.name: serval
facts: Servals have the longest legs relative to body size of any cat.
They are solitary hunters and mark their territory with urine and scent glands.
They can leap 10 feet straight up to catch birds in flight.
Servals have excellent hearing and can detect rodents underground.

calendar.name: siberian husky
facts: They are energetic and require a lot of exercise.
Siberian huskies were originally bred as sled dogs.
They are known for their striking blue or multi-colored eyes and thick double coat.
Siberian huskies are a medium-sized working dog breed.

calendar.name: skunk
facts: They are immune to snake venom and will sometimes eat venomous snakes.
Skunks are known for their ability to spray a foul-smelling liquid as a defense mechanism, which can reach up to 10 feet.
Skunks are nocturnal and have poor eyesight but an excellent sense of smell and hearing.
Before spraying, skunks usually give a warning by stomping their feet or raising their tail.

calendar.name: snail
facts: The largest land snail, the African giant snail, can grow up to 15 inches long.
Snails are hermaphrodites, meaning each individual has both male and female reproductive organs.
Snails can sleep for up to three years if the weather isn't favorable.
They have thousands of tiny teeth on their tongue-like radula, which they use to scrape food.

calendar.name: snow leopard
facts: Snow leopards are known as 'ghosts of the mountains' due to their elusive nature.
They have thick fur and wide, fur-covered feet that act as natural snowshoes.
Snow leopards can leap up to 50 feet in a single bound.
They are unable to roar but communicate with chuffing sounds and growls.

randomAnimals.name: newfoundland
facts: No facts available.

randomAnimals.name: tuatara
facts: They are active at night and feed on insects, lizards, and bird eggs.
The tuatara is a lizard-like reptile from New Zealand that is the only living member of the order Rhynchocephalia, making it a 'living fossil'.
They can live over 100 years, making them one of the longest-living reptiles.
They have a 'third eye' on the top of their head, which is sensitive to light but does not see images.

randomAnimals.name: javan rhino
facts: Javan rhinos are one of the most endangered large mammals in the world, with a population of fewer than 80 individuals.
Their skin looks like armor, with folds forming 'plates' on their body.
They live solitary lives and are very secretive, making them difficult to observe and study.
They are the only rhinos that have only one horn, and in females, it is often very small or absent.
